Comments_List: I had never taken a theory course that was as rigorous as professor Cohn's meter seminar. It was an incredibly difficult class for me but I was able to throw myself into the depths of theoretical rhetoric in a way that I had not engaged with before this semester.
Facility with certain analytic tools, a vocabulary to talk about the temporal aspects of music, and a good number of metric and rhythmic hors-d'oeuvres to fool around with in the brain.

I felt totally overwhelmed at the beginning of the semester and felt that I had to work very hard to catch up to my peers. That said, once things clicked about mid-semester I felt that my understanding of the course material grew exponentially in a very short period of time.

I found the course strong. I don't have much constructive criticism. I guess I'll just say that I always lobby for greater number of musical examplespunctuating classroom talk with actual music helps me learn, and always helps me bring it back to the real topic at hand.
Yes absolutely but I would make sure to let them know that the theoretical background required to comprehend the reading should not be taken lightly
